lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters, household items, and rooms mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “Listen for kitchen, bed, sofa.” Play story. Students point to matching room/item visuals when they hear them.
stretchStrategies: “What Happens Next?” – Story Prediction with Clues
Pause the story before the last panel (SB p.38). Students predict what happens next by discussing in pairs using the sentence frames:
“I think there’s a ___ in the ___. Maybe they...”
After sharing, students watch/read to confirm or revise.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read the story aloud. Assign roles. Students act it out using objects or mime. Then ask follow-up questions: “Where is the lamp?”

supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Stop the story just before the end. Ask: “What do you think happens next?” Students draw a final scene and explain it.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Often confused – Kindergarteners will tend to prefer 'it is' for everything, even though the Vietnamese is very different for the two structures

languageTransferAnalysis.section: 4. Plural forms of it is and there is:
items: Plural forms of these structures do not exist in Vietnamese. It's difficult for kids to remember to produce them, particularly because the plural element comes before the noun phrase. There are two houses
